instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Adiabatic Boundary Conditions -> text
input: What are adiabatic boundary conditions applied to in EnergyPlus?
output: Adiabatic boundary conditions are applied to two surface types in EnergyPlus: 1) Surfaces with adiabatic outside boundary conditions 2) Internal Mass objects.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Adiabatic Boundary Conditions -> text
input: How does EnergyPlus handle boundary conditions for surfaces with adiabatic boundary conditions?
output: For both surface types EnergyPlus will apply the same boundary conditions to each side of the construction so that there is no temperature difference across the surface.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Adiabatic Boundary Conditions -> text
input: What is the result of the dynamic response of the construction to varying inside boundary conditions?
output: In this case all heat transfer into the surface is a result of the dynamic response of the construction to varying inside boundary conditions.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Adiabatic Boundary Conditions -> text
input: Where does the surface store and release heat when adiabatic boundary conditions are applied?
output: The surface will store and release heat only at the inside face of the surface (it is assumed that the outside face is not within the zone).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Adiabatic Boundary Conditions -> text
input: How can a situation be modeled if both faces of the surface are within the zone?
output: If both faces are within the zone this situation can be modeled either by creating another adiabatic or internal mass surface with the reverse construction or for symmetric constructions simply doubling the area of the surface.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Combined Heat and Moisture Transfer (HAMT) Model -> text
input: What is the HAMT solution algorithm?
output: The combined heat and moisture transfer finite (HAMT) solution algorithm is a completely coupled one-dimensional finite element heat and moisture transfer model simulating the movement and storage of heat and moisture in surfaces simultaneously from and to both the internal and external environments.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Combined Heat and Moisture Transfer (HAMT) Model -> text
input: What additional capabilities does the HAMT model have?
output: As well as simulating the effects of moisture buffering HAMT is also able to provide temperature and moisture profiles through composite building walls and help to identify surfaces with high surface humidity.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Combined Heat and Moisture Transfer (HAMT) Model -> text
input: How are dependencies on moisture content heat and vapor pressure indicated in the HAMT nomenclature?
output: Dependencies on moisture content are indicated by a superscript \(^w\) on heat by a superscript \(^h\) and vapor pressure by a superscript \(^v\).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Combined Heat and Moisture Transfer (HAMT) Model -> text

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Combined Heat and Moisture Transfer (HAMT) Model -> equation

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Combined Heat and Moisture Transfer (HAMT) Model -> text

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Combined Heat and Moisture Transfer (HAMT) Model ->
input: chunk = terms in Equation~\refeq:HAMTHeatBalanceEquation describe the storage transport and generation of heat respectively. \beginequation \frac\partial w\partial \phi \frac\partial \phi \partial \tau  = \frac\partial \partial x\left( D^w\frac\partial w\partial \phi \frac\partial \phi \partial x \right) + \frac\partial \partial x\left( \frac\delta \mu \frac\partial p\partial x \right) \labeleq:HAMTMoistureBalanceEquation \endequation The three terms in Equation~\refeq:HAMTMoistureBalanceEquation describe the storage of moisture the transport of liquid moisture and the transport of vapor respectively. The equation to calculate the vapor diffusion coefficient in air (\(\delta\)) used in the third term of both equations is also taken from Künzel \beginequation \delta = \frac\left( 2 \times 10^ - 7 \times \left( T + 273.15 \right)^0.81 \right)p_ambient \endequation The heat storage capacity (\(\frac\partial H\partial T\)) depends on the moisture content w of the material by the following equation. \beginequation \frac\partial H\partial T = \left( c\rho + c^ww \right) \endequation The moisture content of the material w and the vapor diffusion resistance factor $\mu$ depend on the relative humidity inside the material. The parameters \(\frac\partial w\partial \phi\) \(k^w\) ~and \(D^w\) are also moisture dependent parameters. The following sections describe how the above equations are used within the HAMT model. \subsubsectionSurfaces Material Layers and Cells\labelsurfaces-material-layers-and-cells ``Surfaces  are made of a number of layers of potentially any combination of materials. Each surface is split into its constituent materials and is then split up further into cells through its depth. HAMT will generate no more than 10 cells per material with widths that are thinner near the boundaries of each material where most changes are expected and detail is needed. \subsubsectionHeat Transfer\labelheat-transfer Equation~\refeq:HAMTHeatBalanceEquation can be re-written and used to describe the heat storage and transfer through the i\(^th\) cell in a surface. \beginequation \left( c_i\rho_i + c^ww_i \right)\Delta V_i\fracT_i^p + 1 - T_i^p\Delta \tau  = \sum\limits_j k_ij^wA_ij\fracT_j^p + 1 - T_i^p + 1x_ij + \sum\limits_j h_v\frac\delta_ij\mu_ijA_ij\fracp_j^p + 1 - p_i^p + 1x_ij \endequation In the one dimensional case there are only two adjacent cells each labeled j. The heat generated due to vaporization \(q_i^v\) can be calculated separately. \beginequation q_i^v = \sum\limits_j h_v\frac\delta_ij\mu_ijA_ij\fracp_j^p + 1 - p_i^p + 1x_ij \endequation Rearranging Equation~\refeq:HAMTHeatBalanceEquation and including other sources of heat (\(q_i^adds\)) such as radiation from other surfaces in the calculation gives the temperature in a cell in the next time step as \beginequation T_i^p + 1 = \frac\sum\nolimits_j \fracT_j^p + 1R_ij^h + q_i^v + q_i^adds + C_i^h\fracT_i^p\Delta \tau \fracC_i^h\Delta \tau  + \sum\nolimits_j \frac1R_ij^h  \labeleq:TemperatureIthCell \endequation where \(C_i^h = \left( c_i\rho_i + c^ww_i \right)\Delta V_i\) is thermal heat capacitance of cell i and \(R_ij^h = \fracx_ijk_ijA_ij\) ~is the thermal resistance between cells i and j. This equation can be solved using the Gauss-Seidel iteration technique. The i\(^th\) cell temperature is calculated whilst the j\(^th\) cell temperatures are kept as up to date as possible. The iteration is stopped when the maximum difference between two consecutive calculations in all cells is less than a threshold of 0.002°C. \subsubsectionMoisture Content w\labelmoisture-content-w The moisture content (w) of a cell is needed for the calculation of the heat transfer through the cell as it affects the thermal
output: ```json

input: What is the relationship between w and the RH for each material known as?

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Combined Heat and Moisture Transfer (HAMT) Model -> text
input: How does HAMT obtain the moisture content of a material for any RH value?

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Combined Heat and Moisture Transfer (HAMT) Model -> text
input: What is the porosity of a material (P)?
output: The porosity of a material (P) is an input variable and defined as the maximum fraction by volume of a material that can be taken up with moisture.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Combined Heat and Moisture Transfer (HAMT) Model -> text
input: How is porosity used in the HAMT model?
output: It is used to calculate the maximum point on the sorption isotherm curve.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Combined Heat and Moisture Transfer (HAMT) Model -> text
input: How is porosity entered for each material?
output: The porosity is entered for each material via the MaterialProperty:HeatAndMoistureTransfer:Settings object as described in the Input Output Reference document.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Combined Heat and Moisture Transfer (HAMT) Model -> text
input: How is the thermal conductivity (k\\(^w\\)) of the cell determined?
output: The thermal conductivity (k\\(^w\\)) of the cell is determined by interpolating between data points of thermal conductivity versus the moisture content of the material entered into EnergyPlus via the MaterialProperty:HeatAndMoistureTransfer:ThermalConductivity object.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Combined Heat and Moisture Transfer (HAMT) Model -> text

input: What is the purpose of the moisture dependent moisture diffusion coefficient (μ) in the HAMT model?
output: The moisture dependent moisture diffusion coefficient (μ) is used in the third term of the heat balance equation to describe heat transfer due to vapor movement.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Combined Heat and Moisture Transfer (HAMT) Model -> text
input: How is the moisture diffusion coefficient determined?
output: The moisture diffusion coefficient is determined by interpolating between data points of moisture diffusion coefficient versus the moisture content of the material.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Combined Heat and Moisture Transfer (HAMT) Model -> text
input: How is moisture transported through materials?
output: Moisture is transported through materials as either liquid (w) or vapor (p).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Combined Heat and Moisture Transfer (HAMT) Model -> text
input: What drives liquid and vapor transfer in materials?
output: Liquid transfer is driven by differences in relative humidity whereas vapor transfer is driven by differences in vapor pressure.

output: Moisture is transported through materials as either liquid (w) or vapor (p).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Combined Heat and Moisture Transfer (HAMT) Model -> text
input: What capacity do materials have concerning moisture?
output: Materials have a capacity to store moisture.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Combined Heat and Moisture Transfer (HAMT) Model -> text
input: How can Equation~\\refeq:RelativeHumidityIthCell be used?
output: Equation~\\refeq:RelativeHumidityIthCell can be used together with the heat equation~\\refeq:TemperatureIthCell in an alternate step by step fashion to calculate the new temperature and relative humidity profiles for each cell for the next time step.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Combined Heat and Moisture Transfer (HAMT) Model -> text
input: What assumption is made for surfaces with Ground exterior boundary condition?
output: Surfaces with Ground exterior boundary condition assumes saturated air (100\\% relative humidity) condition to calculate the exterior mass transfer coefficient which is used to model mass transport through a ground contact surfaces.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Combined Heat and Moisture Transfer (HAMT) Model -> text
input: What is the Moisture Dependent Liquid Transport Coefficient?
output: The Moisture Dependent Liquid Transport Coefficient is entered as a series of moisture density and liquid transport coefficient data points.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Combined Heat and Moisture Transfer (HAMT) Model -> text
input: What are the two different coefficients for liquid transport?
output: There are two different coefficients one for suction where the surface is wet due to rain and one for redistribution where the surface is no longer wet.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Combined Heat and Moisture Transfer (HAMT) Model -> text
input: How is the weather file's rain flag used?
output: If the weather file has a rain flag it is used to switch between the two types of coefficient: HAMT-SUCTION and HAMT-REDISTRIBUTION.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Combined Heat and Moisture Transfer (HAMT) Model -> text
input: What is Moisture Dependent Moisture Capacity \\(\\frac\\partial w\\partial \\phi\\)?
output: This is simply the gradient of moisture sorption isotherm at the RH of the material.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Combined Heat and Moisture Transfer (HAMT) Model -> text
input: What are the internal and external heat transfer coefficients used for?
output: The internal and external heat transfer coefficients are used to calculate the thermal resistance of the boundary layer between the zone air and the surface of the surface.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Combined Heat and Moisture Transfer (HAMT) Model -> text
input: How can the heat transfer coefficients be supplied?
output: They are either supplied by the user via the advanced surface concepts object 'SurfaceProperty:ConvectionCoefficients' or if these are not provided dynamic values are calculated.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Combined Heat and Moisture Transfer (HAMT) Model -> text
input: What are the internal and external vapor transfer coefficients used for?
output: The internal and external vapor transfer coefficients are used to calculate the resistance to vapor transfer of the boundary layer between the zone air and the surface of the surface.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Combined Heat and Moisture Transfer (HAMT) Model -> text
input: How can the vapor transfer coefficients be supplied?
output: They are also either supplied by the user via the advanced surface concept object SurfaceProperties:VaporCoefficients. If these are not provided then dynamic values are calculated based on the convective heat transfer coefficients.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Combined Heat and Moisture Transfer (HAMT) Model -> text
input: What assumption is made for surfaces with a Ground exterior boundary condition?
output: Surfaces with Ground exterior boundary condition assume saturated air (100% relative humidity) condition to calculate the exterior mass transfer coefficient which is used to model mass transport through ground contact surfaces.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Liquid Transport Coefficient D^w -> text
input: What is the Liquid Transport Coefficient D^w and how is it used?
output: The Moisture Dependent Liquid Transport Coefficient is entered as a series of moisture density and liquid transport coefficient data points. There are two different coefficients: one for suction where the surface is wet due to rain and one for redistribution where the surface is no longer wet.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Liquid Transport Coefficient D^w -> text
input: How does the weather file affect the Liquid Transport Coefficient?
output: If the weather file has a rain flag it is used to switch between the two types of coefficients: HAMT-SUCTION and HAMT-REDISTRIBUTION.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Moisture Dependent Moisture Capacity ∂w/∂φ -> text
input: What is the Moisture Dependent Moisture Capacity ∂w/∂φ?
output: It is simply the gradient of the moisture sorption isotherm at the relative humidity of the material.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Convective Heat Transfer -> text
input: How are the internal and external heat transfer coefficients used?
output: The internal and external heat transfer coefficients are used to calculate the thermal resistance of the boundary layer between the zone air and the surface of the surface.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Convective Heat Transfer -> text
input: How are the heat transfer coefficients supplied or calculated?
output: They are either supplied by the user via the advanced surface concepts object 'SurfaceProperty:ConvectionCoefficients' or if these are not provided dynamic values are calculated.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Convective Vapor Transfer -> text
input: What role do the internal and external vapor transfer coefficients play?
output: The internal and external vapor transfer coefficients are used to calculate the resistance to vapor transfer of the boundary layer between the zone air and the surface of the surface.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Convective Vapor Transfer -> text
input: How are the vapor transfer coefficients determined?
output: They are either supplied by the user via the advanced surface concept object 'SurfaceProperties:VaporCoefficients'. If these are not provided dynamic values are calculated based on the convective heat transfer coefficients.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Initial Moisture Content -> text
input: Why are 'warm up' days used at the start of an EnergyPlus simulation?
output: 'Warm up' days are used to ensure that the temperatures of surfaces come to equilibrium with the environment before the simulation starts proper.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Initial Moisture Content -> text
input: Why is it necessary to set initial moisture content values for each material?
output: Moisture content within some building fabrics can take a very long time to come to equilibrium with its environment so it is necessary to set initial or typical values of moisture content for each material to be used at the start of the simulation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Initial Moisture Content -> text
input: How are initial values of moisture content entered for each material?
output: These initial values are entered for each material via the 'MaterialProperty:HeatAndMoistureTransfer:Settings' object as described in the Input Output Reference document.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Using the Model -> text
input: What materials are provided in the EnergyPlus Reference DataSets for the HAMT model?
output: The material properties for a small sample of six generic materials have been provided in the EnergyPlus Reference DataSets (MoistureMaterials.idf).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Using the Model -> text
input: Where were the material properties for the HAMT model synthesized from?
output: The properties were synthesized from the Annex 24 database [Kumar Kumaran M. (1996)] supplemented when required by data from the database of the WUFI model [WUFI (1999)].

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Using the Model -> text
input: What should users consult when specific material properties are required?
output: Users should consult material property catalogues and other primary sources when the properties of a specific material are required.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Using the Model -> text
input: How does EnergyPlus with HAMT calculate room air temperature and moisture content?
output: Moisture and heat from the surfaces are used by EnergyPlus to calculate the room air temperature and moisture content.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Using the Model -> text
input: What is the recommended time step for EnergyPlus with HAMT?
output: EnergyPlus with HAMT works best with as short a time step as possible. However the optimum time step will depend on the nature of the weather and type of building.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Using the Model -> text
input: What time step is needed for buildings with frequent and large temperature changes?
output: Buildings with frequent and large changes in internal and external temperature will need a small time step maybe even 60 steps per hour.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Using the Model -> text
input: What time step is sufficient for slowly evolving temperatures and relative humidities?
output: Slowly evolving temperatures and relative humidities will not require such a short time step and 20 or even 6 steps per hour may be sufficient.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: References -> text
input: Who authored the reference on simultaneous heat and moisture transport in building components?
output: The reference is authored by Künzel H.M. (1995).

input: What is the purpose of warm-up days in the simulation process?
output: Warm-up days are used to ensure that the temperatures of surfaces come to equilibrium with the environment before the simulation starts proper.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Combined Heat and Moisture Transfer (HAMT) Model -> text

input: How are initial moisture content values entered for each material?
output: These initial values are entered for each material via the MaterialProperty:HeatAndMoistureTransfer:Settings object as described in the Input Output Reference document.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Combined Heat and Moisture Transfer (HAMT) Model -> text
input: What is provided in the EnergyPlus Reference DataSets as an illustration of the use of the HAMT model?

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Combined Heat and Moisture Transfer (HAMT) Model -> text
input: How does EnergyPlus use moisture and heat from surfaces?

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Combined Heat and Moisture Transfer (HAMT) Model -> text
input: What is the recommended time step for EnergyPlus with HAMT?
output: EnergyPlus with HAMT works best with as short a time step as possible.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Combined Heat and Moisture Transfer (HAMT) Model -> text
input: What factors influence the optimum time step for EnergyPlus with HAMT?
output: The optimum time step depends on the nature of the weather and type of building. Buildings with frequent and large changes in internal and external temperature will need a small time step maybe even 60 steps per hour while slowly evolving temperatures and relative humidities will not require such a short time step and 20 or even 6 steps per hour may be sufficient.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: References -> text
input: Who authored the reference on simultaneous heat and moisture transport in building components?
output: The reference is authored by Künzel H.M. (1995).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: References -> text
input: What edition of 'Heat Transfer' by Holman is referenced?
output: The Ninth Edition of 'Heat Transfer' by Holman J.P. (2002) is referenced.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: References -> text
input: What is the Oxford Chemistry Primers number for Winterton's 'Heat Transfer'?
output: The Oxford Chemistry Primers number for Winterton's 'Heat Transfer' is 50.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: References -> text
input: Which report by Kumar Kumaran is referenced?
output: The IEA ANNEX 24 Final Report Volume 3 by Kumar Kumaran M. (1996) is referenced.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: References -> text
input: What version of WUFI is referenced?
output: Version 2.2 of WUFI (1999) is referenced.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Conduction Finite Difference Solution Algorithm -> text
input: What fundamental principles do EnergyPlus models follow?
output: EnergyPlus models follow fundamental heat balance principles very closely in almost all aspects of the program.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Conduction Finite Difference Solution Algorithm -> text
input: What has the simulation of building surface constructions relied on?
output: The simulation of building surface constructions has relied on a conduction transfer function (CTF) transformation carried over from BLAST.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Conduction Finite Difference Solution Algorithm -> text
input: What are the usual restrictions of a transformation-based solution?
output: The usual restrictions of a transformation-based solution include constant properties fixed values of some parameters and not producing results for the interior of the surface.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Conduction Finite Difference Solution Algorithm -> text
input: Why is it necessary to step back from transformations to more fundamental forms?
output: As the energy analysis field moves toward simulating more advanced constructions such as phase change materials (PCM) it becomes necessary to step back from transformations to more fundamental forms.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Conduction Finite Difference Solution Algorithm -> text
input: What solution algorithm has been incorporated into EnergyPlus?
output: A conduction finite difference (CondFD) solution algorithm has been incorporated into EnergyPlus.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Conduction Finite Difference Solution Algorithm -> text
input: Does the CondFD solution algorithm replace the CTF solution algorithm?
output: No the CondFD solution algorithm does not replace the CTF solution algorithm but complements it for cases where the user needs to simulate phase change materials or variable thermal conductivity.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Conduction Finite Difference Solution Algorithm -> text
input: What is possible to use for zone time steps as short as one minute?
output: It is possible to use the finite difference algorithm for zone time steps as short as one minute.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Conduction Finite Difference Solution Algorithm -> text
input: How many different options does EnergyPlus include for the specific scheme or formulation used for the finite difference model?
output: EnergyPlus includes two different options for the specific scheme or formulation used for the finite difference model.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Conduction Finite Difference Solution Algorithm -> text
input: What is the first scheme referred to as?
output: The first scheme is referred to as Crank-Nicholson and was the formulation used in EnergyPlus prior to version 7.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Conduction Finite Difference Solution Algorithm -> text
input: What scheme was added as of version 7?
output: As of version 7 a second scheme was added and is referred to as fully implicit.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Conduction Finite Difference Solution Algorithm -> text
input: How can the selection between the two schemes be made?
output: The selection between the two can be made by the user with the HeatBalanceSettings:ConductionFiniteDifference input object.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Conduction Finite Difference Solution Algorithm -> text
input: Once selected how is the scheme used throughout the simulation?
output: Once selected the same scheme is used throughout the simulation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Conduction Finite Difference Solution Algorithm -> text
input: What do the two different schemes share?
output: Although the two different schemes differ in their fundamental heat transfer equations they share nearly all the same supporting models for material properties data storage solution schemes and spatial discretization algorithms.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Conduction Finite Difference Solution Algorithm -> text
input: What is the Crank-Nicholson scheme based on?
output: The Crank-Nicholson scheme is semi-implicit and based on an Adams-Moulton solution approach. It is considered second-order in time.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Conduction Finite Difference Solution Algorithm -> text
input: What does the algorithm use to account for phase change energy accurately?
output: The algorithm uses an implicit finite difference scheme coupled with an enthalpy-temperature function to account for phase change energy accurately.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Conduction Finite Difference Solution Algorithm -> equation
input: What is the implicit formulation for an internal node?
output: The implicit formulation for an internal node is shown in the equation: \nC_p \\rho \\Delta x \\fracT_i^j+1-T_i^j\\Delta t = \\frac12\\left(k_W\\fracT_i+1^j+1-T_i^j+1\\Delta x + k_E\\fracT_i-1^j+1-T_i^j+1\\Delta x + k_W\\fracT_i+1^j-T_i^j\\Delta x + k_E\\fracT_i-1^j-T_i^j\\Delta x\\right)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Conduction Finite Difference Solution Algorithm -> text
input: What does the variable T represent in the equation?
output: The variable T represents node temperature.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Conduction Finite Difference Solution Algorithm -> text
input: What does the variable Δt represent in the equation?
output: The variable Δt represents the calculation time step.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Conduction Finite Difference Solution Algorithm -> text
input: What does the variable Δx represent in the equation?
output: The variable Δx represents the finite difference layer thickness (always less than construction layer thickness).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Conduction Finite Difference Solution Algorithm -> text
input: What does the variable Cp represent in the equation?
output: The variable Cp represents the specific heat of the material.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Conduction Finite Difference Solution Algorithm -> text
input: What does the variable k_W represent in the equation?

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Conduction Finite Difference Solution Algorithm -> text

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Conduction Finite Difference Solution Algorithm -> equation
input: What is the equation that relates enthalpy and temperature?
output: The equation that relates enthalpy and temperature is: \nh_i = \\textHTF\\left(T_i\\right)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Conduction Finite Difference Solution Algorithm -> text
input: What is HTF in the enthalpy-temperature equation?

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Conduction Finite Difference Solution Algorithm -> text
input: What is the fully implicit scheme based on?
output: The fully implicit scheme is also based on an Adams-Moulton solution approach. It is considered first order in time.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Conduction Finite Difference Solution Algorithm -> equation
input: What is the model equation for the fully implicit scheme?
output: The model equation for the fully implicit scheme is: \nC_p\\rho \\Delta x \\fracT_i^j + 1 - T_i^j\\Delta t = \\left( k_W\\fracT_i + 1^j + 1 - T_i^j + 1\\Delta x + k_E\\fracT_i - 1^j + 1 - T_i^j + 1\\Delta x \\right)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Conduction Finite Difference Solution Algorithm -> text
input: What is the considered order in time for the solution approach?
output: It is considered second-order in time.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Conduction Finite Difference Solution Algorithm -> text
input: What scheme does the algorithm use to account for phase change energy accurately?
output: The algorithm uses an implicit finite difference scheme coupled with an enthalpy-temperature function to account for phase change energy accurately.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Conduction Finite Difference Solution Algorithm -> equation
input: What is the implicit formulation for an internal node?
output: \\beginequation C_p \\rho \\Delta x \\fracT_i^j+1-T_i^j\\Delta t = \\frac12\\left(k_W\\fracT_i+1^j+1-T_i^j+1\\Delta x + k_E\\fracT_i-1^j+1-T_i^j+1\\Delta x + k_W\\fracT_i+1^j-T_i^j\\Delta x + k_E\\fracT_i-1^j-T_i^j\\Delta x\\right) \\endequation

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Conduction Finite Difference Solution Algorithm -> text
input: What types of nodes does EnergyPlus use for both schemes?
output: EnergyPlus uses the following four types of nodes: (1) interior surface nodes (2) interior nodes (3) material interface nodes and (4) external surface nodes.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Conduction Finite Difference Solution Algorithm -> text
input: How is the grid for each material established?
output: The grid for each material is established by specifying a half node for each edge of a material and equal size nodes for the rest of the material.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Conduction Finite Difference Solution Algorithm -> text
input: How are equations like the internal node implicit equation formed?
output: Equations such as the internal node implicit equation are formed for all nodes in a construction.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Conduction Finite Difference Solution Algorithm -> text
input: Is the formulation of all node types the same?
output: The formulation of all node types is basically the same.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Conduction Finite Difference Solution Algorithm -> figure in /UAStudy/EnergyPlus/doc/engineering-reference/media/
input: What does the figure depict in the context of the Conduction Finite Difference Model?
output: The figure depicts the node depiction for the Conduction Finite Difference Model.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Conduction Finite Difference Solution Algorithm -> text
input: What factors does surface discretization depend on in the CondFD model?
output: Surface discretization depends on the thermal diffusivity of the material (\\alpha) and time step (\\Delta t) selected.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Conduction Finite Difference Solution Algorithm -> equation
input: What is the equation that shows the relationship between thermal diffusivity time step and space discretization?
output: \\beginequation Fo = \\frac\\alpha \\Delta t\\Delta x^2 \\endequation

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Conduction Finite Difference Solution Algorithm -> text
input: What is the default value of the space discretization constant and what is it based on?
output: The default value of 3 for the space discretization constant C is the inverse of a grid Fourier Number and is based on the stability requirement for the explicit mode.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Conduction Finite Difference Solution Algorithm -> text
input: What stability requirement does the explicit mode have?
output: The explicit mode requires values higher than 2 or a Fourier number lower than 0.5.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Conduction Finite Difference Solution Algorithm -> text
input: Do implicit schemes have the same stability requirements as the explicit mode?
output: Implicit schemes do not have the same stability requirements as the explicit mode.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Conduction Finite Difference Solution Algorithm -> text
input: How was the default value of 3 for the space discretization constant originally set?
output: The default 3 was originally set rather arbitrarily.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Conduction Finite Difference Solution Algorithm -> text
input: How can the value of the space discretization constant be controlled as of version 7?
output: The value of this constant can be controlled by the user with the input field called Space Discretization Constant in the HeatBalanceSettings:ConductionFiniteDifference input object.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Conduction Finite Difference Solution Algorithm -> text
input: What does the discretization method allow CondFD to do?
output: The discretization method allows CondFD to assign different node spacing or grid size to different material layers in a wall or roof.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Conduction Finite Difference Solution Algorithm -> equation
input: What is the equation used to calculate node spacing?
output: \\beginequation \\Delta x = \\sqrt \\textC\\alpha \\Delta t \\endequation
