instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: ScriptF -> text
input: Who developed the \ScriptF\ algorithm?
output: The \ScriptF\ algorithm was developed by Hottel (Hottel and Sarofim Radiative Transfer Chapter 3 McGraw Hill 1967).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: ScriptF -> text
input: What does the \ScriptF\ procedure rely on?
output: The \ScriptF\ procedure relies on a matrix of exchange coefficients between pairs of surfaces that include all exchange paths between the surfaces.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What are the two limiting cases for internal LW radiation exchange?
output: The two limiting cases for internal LW radiation exchange are: 1) The zone air is completely transparent to LW radiation. 2) The zone air completely absorbs LW radiation from the surfaces within the zone.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What is the significance of the completely absorbing air model?
output: The completely absorbing air model is attractive because it can be formulated simply using a combined radiation and convection heat transfer coefficient from each surface to the zone air.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: Why does EnergyPlus treat air as completely transparent in the heat balance formulation?
output: EnergyPlus treats air as completely transparent because it oversimplifies the zone surface exchange problem and this means that air does not participate in the LW radiation exchange among the surfaces in the zone.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What are the physical reasons for considering room air as completely transparent?
output: The model considering room air as completely transparent is reasonable physically because of the low water vapor concentrations and the short mean path lengths.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What is an important attribute of the heat balance method?
output: An important attribute of the heat balance method is that it permits separating the radiant and convective parts of the heat transfer at the surface.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What model does EnergyPlus use for longwave radiation among zone surfaces?
output: EnergyPlus uses a grey interchange model for the longwave radiation among zone surfaces.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What are the two algorithms offered by EnergyPlus for modeling long wave radiation?
output: EnergyPlus offers two algorithms for modeling long wave radiation: the ScriptF method and the CarrollMRT methods.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: How can users select between the two algorithms for modeling long wave radiation in EnergyPlus?
output: Users can select between the two algorithms using the PerformancePrecisionTradeoffs object.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: Who developed the ScriptF algorithm and what is its basis?
output: The ScriptF algorithm was developed by Hottel and it relies on a matrix of exchange coefficients between pairs of surfaces that include all exchange paths between the surfaces.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What assumptions are made in the ScriptF algorithm?
output: The major assumptions in the ScriptF algorithm are that all surface radiation properties are grey and all radiation is diffuse.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What complicating factors are present in finding direct view factors in building rooms and zones?
output: Complicating factors include the unknown location of surfaces such as thermal mass representing furniture and partitions and the computational intensity of calculating direct view factors even if all surface positions are known.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What is EnergyPlus's procedure to approximate direct view factors?
output: EnergyPlus's procedure to approximate direct view factors involves two steps: 1) Determine the total area of other surfaces seen by a surface. 2) Approximate the direct view factor from surface 1 to surface 2 as the ratio of the area of surface 2 to the total area seen by surface 1.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What constraints are there in determining the 'seen' area for view factors?
output: Constraints include: No surface sees itself; all surfaces see thermal mass surfaces; no surface facing within 10 degrees of another surface is seen by the other surface; all surfaces see roofs floors and ceilings (subject to the facing direction constraint).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What operation does EnergyPlus perform if approximate view factors do not satisfy reciprocity and completeness?
output: EnergyPlus performs a view factor fix operation before they are used in the ScriptF determination.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What is a limitation when enforcing 'completeness' in view factors for a zone?
output: A limitation is that if a user includes less than four surfaces in a zone the enforcement of 'completeness' is not strictly possible because it is not possible to have a completed enclosure with less than four surfaces.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What are the major assumptions made in the surface radiation properties for building zone interchange?
output: The major assumptions are that all surface radiation properties are grey and all radiation is diffuse.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: Why are the assumptions of grey surface radiation properties and diffuse radiation reasonable?
output: Both assumptions are reasonable for building zone interchange.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: How are the ScriptF coefficients developed?
output: The ScriptF coefficients are developed by starting with the traditional direct radiation view factors.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What complicating factors exist in finding the direct view factors in building rooms and zones?
output: In the case of building rooms and zones complicating factors include the unknown location of surfaces such as thermal mass representing furniture and partitions.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What is a limitation of calculating direct view factors?
output: The exact calculation of direct view factors is computationally very intensive even if the positions of all surfaces are known.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What procedure does EnergyPlus use to approximate direct view factors?
output: EnergyPlus uses a procedure with two steps: 1) Determine the total area of other surfaces 'seen' by a surface. 2) Approximate the direct view factor from surface 1 to surface 2 as the ratio of the area of surface 2 to the total area 'seen' by surface 1.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What constraints are there in determining the 'seen' area?
output: Constraints include: no surface sees itself all surfaces see thermal mass surfaces no surface facing within 10 degrees of another surface is seen by the other surface and all surfaces see roofs floors and ceilings (subject to the facing direction constraint).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What operation does EnergyPlus perform before using approximate view factors in ScriptF determination?
output: EnergyPlus performs a view factor fix operation to ensure reciprocity and completeness.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What happens if a user includes less than four surfaces in a zone?
output: Reciprocity is enforced initially and view factors from each surface are summed but completeness cannot be strictly enforced. The largest surface will end up having view factors that sum up to greater than unity so the entire view factor matrix is divided by the largest summation of view factors to correct this.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What is done when there are four or more surfaces in a zone but one surface is much larger?
output: Reciprocity is enforced and if completeness cannot be enforced without the large surface seeing itself the surface is allowed to see itself. The calculation of Script F values proceeds via iteration until both completeness and reciprocity are satisfied.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What types of zones might require allowing a large surface to see itself?
output: Very 'flat' zones where one or two surfaces have a much larger area than others such as Trombe Walls large single-story interior areas modeled as a single zone or spaces with a large internal mass element.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What role do thermal mass surfaces play in internal long-wave radiation exchange?
output: Thermal mass surfaces participate in internal long-wave radiation exchange and must have view factors calculated.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What does EnergyPlus produce for cases with less than four surfaces or a very large surface?
output: Warning messages are produced for both of these cases.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What is enforced initially in the situation described?
output: Reciprocity is enforced initially.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What happens when view factors are summed from each surface?
output: When dealing with few surfaces the largest surface in the zone will end up having view factors that sum up to greater than unity after reciprocity is enforced.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: How is the issue of view factors summing to greater than unity corrected?
output: The entire view factor matrix is divided by the largest summation of view factors for any surface in the zone.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What is maintained by dividing the entire view factor matrix by the same value?
output: The reciprocity established by the standard algorithm is maintained and completeness for one surface is established.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: Will all surfaces have view factors that sum up to unity after this correction?
output: No not all surfaces will have view factors that sum up to unity but they will not sum up to greater than unity.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What happens when there are four or more surfaces in a zone with one surface having a large area?
output: Reciprocity only is enforced and in some cases the large surface is allowed to see itself.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What is the suggested action for the extra-large surface case?
output: The suggested action is to divide the large surface into several smaller surfaces.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> equation
input: What equation is used to calculate the longwave radiant exchange for each surface?
output: The equation used is: \\( q_ij = A_iF_ij\\left( T_i^4 - T_j^4 \\right) \\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What does the Carroll method approximate?
output: The Carroll method approximates gray-body long-wave radiation exchange within an enclosure.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What does the mean radiant temperature node act as in the Carroll method?
output: The mean radiant temperature node acts as a clearinghouse for the radiation heat exchange between surfaces.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What is the complexity of the Carroll method compared to the current dense-matrix solution?
output: The Carroll method has linear complexity compared to the \\(O(n^2)\\) complexity of the current dense-matrix solution.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> equation
input: What is the equation used to calculate the mean radiant temperature view factor \\(F_i\\)?
output: The equation used is: \\( F_i=\\frac11-\\fracA_i F_i\\sum_1^nA_j F_j  \\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What should be done with the results to ensure they are reasonable?
output: The results should be examined very carefully to ascertain that they are reasonable.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What is the suggested action for an extra-large surface?
output: The suggested action for the second case (the extra-large surface) is to divide the large surface into several smaller surfaces; then the enclosure will be treated as normal.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> equation
input: What equation is used to calculate the longwave radiant exchange for each surface?
output: \\beginequation q_ij = A_iF_ij\\left( T_i^4 - T_j^4 \\right) \\endequation

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What does \\textbf\\emphF\\(_ij\\) represent?
output: \\textbf\\emphF\\(_ij\\) is the ScriptF between surfaces i and j.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What is the Carroll method an approximation of?
output: The Carroll method is an approximation of gray-body long-wave radiation exchange within an enclosure.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: How does the Carroll method simplify surface-to-surface radiation exchange?
output: The Carroll method simplifies the surface-to-surface radiation exchange by using a single mean radiant temperature node $Tr$ that acts as a clearinghouse for the radiation heat exchange between surfaces.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What is the complexity of the Carroll method compared to the current dense-matrix solution?
output: Unlike the $O(n^2)$ complexity of the current dense-matrix solution the Carroll method has linear complexity.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What is the first step in calculating the mean radiant temperature?
output: The first step in calculating the mean radiant temperature is the calculation of the mean radiant temperature 'view factor' $Fi$.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> equation
input: How is the view factor $Fi$ calculated?
output: \\beginequation F_i=\\frac11-\\fracA_i F_i\\sum_1^nA_j F_j  \\endequation

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: Why must the collection of all 'view factors' be solved iteratively?
output: Because of the circular reference in this equation the collection of all 'view factors' must be solved iteratively but only once per simulation as surface areas do not change throughout.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What is the second step in calculating the mean radiant temperature?
output: The second step is calculating the gray-body radiation resistance $F i$.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> equation
input: How is the gray-body radiation resistance $F i$ calculated?
output: \\beginequation F _i=\\frac\\sigma\\varepsilon_i\\frac\\varepsilon_iF_i +1-\\varepsilon_i \\endequation

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What is the third step in calculating the mean radiant temperature?
output: The third step is calculating the mean radiant temperature $Tr$.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> equation
input: How is the mean radiant temperature $Tr$ calculated?
output: \\beginequation T_r=\\frac\\sum_1^nA_i F _i T_i\\sum_1^nA_i F _i \\endequation

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: Once the mean radiant temperature is known how can the net radiation heat transfer for each surface be calculated?
output: Once the mean radiant temperature is known the net radiation heat transfer for each surface can be calculated as: \\beginequation q=F _i A_i (T_r^4-T_i^4) \\endequation

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What is the effect of furniture in a zone?
output: Furniture in a zone has the effect of increasing the amount of surface area that can participate in the radiation and convection heat exchanges.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What additional effect does furniture have in a zone?
output: It also adds participating thermal mass to the zone.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: How do the changes caused by furniture affect the zone?
output: These two changes both affect the response to temperature changes in the zone and also affect the heat extraction characteristics.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What does the heat balance formulation allow regarding the effect of furniture?
output: The heat balance formulation allows the effect to be modeled in a realistic manner by including the furniture surface area and thermal mass in the heat exchange process.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What is the traditional model for LW radiation from internal sources?
output: The traditional model for this source is to define a radiative/convective split.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What is the gray-body radiation resistance denoted by?
output: The gray-body radiation resistance is denoted by $F_i$.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: When must the gray-body radiation resistance be computed?
output: This calculation must be computed every time surface emissivity changes.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> equation
input: What is the equation for calculating $F_i$?
output: $F_i = \\frac\\sigma\\varepsilon_i\\frac\\varepsilon_iF_i + 1 - \\varepsilon_i$

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What is the mean radiant temperature denoted by?
output: The mean radiant temperature is denoted by $T_r$.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> equation
input: What is the equation for calculating the mean radiant temperature $T_r$?
output: $T_r = \\frac\\sum_1^n A_i F_i T_i\\sum_1^n A_i F_i$

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What can be calculated once the mean radiant temperature is known?
output: Once the mean radiant temperature is known the net radiation heat transfer for each surface can be calculated.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> equation
input: What is the equation for calculating the net radiation heat transfer for each surface?

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What is the effect of furniture in a zone?
output: Furniture in a zone increases the amount of surface area that can participate in radiation and convection heat exchanges and adds participating thermal mass to the zone.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: How does furniture affect the zone?
output: Furniture affects the response to temperature changes in the zone and affects the heat extraction characteristics.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What does the proper modeling of furniture require?
output: The proper modeling of furniture requires further research but the heat balance formulation allows the effect to be modeled realistically by including furniture surface area and thermal mass in the heat exchange process.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What is the traditional model for LW radiation from internal sources?
output: The traditional model defines a radiative/convective split for heat introduced into a zone from equipment distributing the radiative part over surfaces within the zone.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: Why is the traditional model for LW radiation from internal sources not completely realistic?
output: It departs from heat balance principles and requires knowledge of placement and surface temperatures of all equipment which is virtually impossible.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: How is short-wave radiation from lights distributed?
output: Short-wave radiation from lights is distributed over the surfaces in the zone in a prescribed manner.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: How is transmitted solar radiation distributed?
output: Transmitted solar radiation is distributed over the surfaces in the zone in a prescribed manner.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What would be required to calculate the actual position of beam solar radiation?
output: Calculating the actual position of beam solar radiation would involve partial surface irradiation inconsistent with the current zone model.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What does the current procedure for transmitted solar radiation incorporate?
output: The current procedures incorporate a set of prescribed distributions.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What can the heat balance approach deal with?
output: The heat balance approach can deal with any distribution function allowing changes if appropriate.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> equation
input: What is the equation for calculating convection flux?
output: $q _conv = h_c(T_s - T_a)$

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What can the inside convection coefficients be based on?
output: The inside convection coefficients can be based on correlations for natural mixed and forced convection.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What is the contribution to the inside surface heat balance?
output: The contribution to the inside surface heat balance is the wall conduction term \(q _ki\).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: How is heat introduced into a zone from equipment managed?
output: The radiative part is distributed over the surfaces within the zone in some prescribed manner but this model is not completely realistic and departs from heat balance principles.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: Why is it difficult to treat the heat source from equipment in more detail?
output: It is virtually impossible to treat this source in more detail since it would require knowledge of the placement and surface temperatures of all equipment.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: How is short wavelength radiation from lights distributed in a zone?
output: The short wavelength radiation from lights is distributed over the surfaces in the zone in some prescribed manner.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: How is transmitted solar radiation handled in the zone model?
output: Transmitted solar radiation is distributed over the surfaces in the zone in a prescribed manner as calculating the actual position of beam solar radiation would involve partial surface irradiation which is inconsistent with the rest of the zone model.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What flexibility does the heat balance approach provide regarding distribution functions?
output: The heat balance approach can deal with any distribution function allowing the distribution function to be changed if appropriate.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> equation
input: What equation is used to calculate the convection flux to zone air?
output: The convection flux is calculated using the equation: \\( q_conv = h_c(T_s - T_a) \\).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What models are used for calculating inside convection coefficients?
output: The implementation uses coefficients based on correlations for natural mixed and forced convection.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What is the role of the wall conduction term in the inside surface heat balance?
output: The wall conduction term represented by \\( q_ki \\) contributes to the inside surface heat balance by representing the heat transfer to the inside face of the building element.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What formulation is used to determine the heat flux for interior conduction?
output: A CTF formulation is used to determine the heat flux for interior conduction.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What options are available for modeling inside convection coefficients in EnergyPlus?
output: There are four different settings to direct how EnergyPlus managers select \\( h_c \\) models during a simulation with numerous individual model equations for different situations.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: How can the convection coefficients on the inside of any surface be overridden?
output: The convection coefficients can be overridden using the \SurfaceProperty:ConvectionCoefficients\ object in the input file to set the convection coefficient value directly or with schedules.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: How is \\( h_c \\) adjusted for exterior simple-glazing windows?
output: For exterior simple-glazing windows modeled with the WindowMaterial:SimpleGlazingSystem object \\( h_c \\) is scaled with an adjustment ratio to model simple windows with highly conductive frames.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What is the adaptive convection algorithm?
output: The adaptive convection algorithm developed by Beausoleil-Morrison is a methodology for dynamically managing the selection of \\( h_c \\) equations.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What formulation is used to determine the heat flux for the building element?
output: A CTF formulation is used to determine this heat flux.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What are the different modeling options available in EnergyPlus for inside convection coefficients?
output: There are many different modeling options available in EnergyPlus for inside convection coefficients h_c.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: How many settings are there to direct how EnergyPlus managers select h_c models during a simulation?
output: There are four different settings to direct how EnergyPlus managers select h_c models during a simulation.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What do the individual model equations for h_c in EnergyPlus cover?
output: The individual model equations for h_c in EnergyPlus cover different situations that arise from surface orientations room airflow conditions and heat flow direction.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What is noted about multiple researchers developing competing models for the same situations?
output: In many cases multiple researchers have developed competing models for the same situations that differ and there is no way to declare one is better than another.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: How is the overall default for the simulation selected?
output: An overall default for the simulation is selected in the 'SurfaceConvectionAlgorithm:Inside' object and can be overridden by selecting a different option in a zone description.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: How can convection coefficients on the inside of any surface be overridden?
output: It is possible to override the convection coefficients on the inside of any surface by using the 'SurfaceProperty:ConvectionCoefficients' object in the input file to set the convection coefficient value on the inside of any surface.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: How can the values for convection coefficients be specified?
output: The values can be specified directly or with schedules.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: Where are specific details about convection coefficients given?
output: Specific details are given in the Input Output Reference document.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: How is h_c scaled for exterior simple-glazing windows modeled with the WindowMaterial:SimpleGlazingSystem object?
output: For exterior simple-glazing windows modeled with the WindowMaterial:SimpleGlazingSystem object h_c is scaled with an adjustment ratio.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What does the adjustment ratio enable in the modeling of simple windows?
output: The adjustment ratio enables the modeling of simple windows with highly conductive frames (large input U values).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: Where is the calculation of the adjustment ratio detailed?
output: The calculation of the adjustment ratio is detailed in Section~\\refapplication-issues.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: Who developed the adaptive convection algorithm?
output: Beausoleil-Morrison (2000 2002) developed the adaptive convection algorithm.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What is the purpose of the adaptive convection algorithm?
output: The adaptive convection algorithm is used to select among the available h_c equations for the one that is most appropriate for a given surface at a given time.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What does Beausoleil-Morrison note about the adaptive convection algorithm?
output: Beausoleil-Morrison notes that the adaptive convection algorithm is intended to be expanded and altered to reflect different classification schemes and/or new h_c equations.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: How has the implementation of the adaptive convection algorithm in EnergyPlus been modified?
output: The implementation in EnergyPlus has been modified in the following ways: an input mechanism is provided for customizing h_c equation selections no distinction is made between zones with different heater positions and certain correlations and models are not used or combined.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What is provided to customize the specific selections of h_c equations?
output: An input mechanism is provided (see the SurfaceConvectionAlgorithm:Inside:AdapativeModelSelections object) to customize the specific selections of h_c equations.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What distinction is avoided in the adaptive convection algorithm regarding ZoneHVAC-type equipment?
output: There is no distinction between zones that have convective zone heater equipment located underneath the windows and those that have convective heaters located away from the windows.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What terminology does Beausoleil-Morrison use for the regimes that are combined?
output: Using Beausoleil-Morrison's terminology regimes B1 and B2 are combined into just one B regime.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What correlation is not used in the adaptive convection algorithm?
output: The correlation for horizontal free jet developed by Fisher (1995) is not used.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What models are used for all mechanical circulation from central air system?
output: Ceiling diffuser models are used for all mechanical circulation from central air system.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: Why was the decision made to use ceiling diffuser models for mechanical circulation?
output: This decision was made to avoid requiring additional user input on the position of and momentum generated by air terminal units and because Fisher (1995) found that the Coanda effect is so significant that in practice a free horizontal jet is difficult to maintain.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What does Beausoleil-Morrison note about the adaptive convection algorithm?
output: Beausoleil-Morrison notes that the adaptive convection algorithm is intended to be expanded and altered to reflect different classification schemes and/or new h_c equations.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: How has the implementation in EnergyPlus been modified from the original?
output: The implementation in EnergyPlus has been modified from the original by providing an input mechanism for customizing h_c equations avoiding distinctions in zone equipment positioning not using Fisher's correlation for horizontal free jets supporting arbitrary geometry and including additional categories for tilted surfaces.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What is the purpose of the input mechanism provided in EnergyPlus?
output: The input mechanism is provided so that the user can customize the specific selections of h_c equations that are applied for different flow regimes and surface orientations.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: Why is there no distinction between zones with convective heaters located under windows and those away from windows?
output: To avoid requiring additional user input on the position of ZoneHVAC-type equipment within a zone there is no distinction between zones with convective heaters located under windows and those away from windows.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What air flow regimes are combined into one in EnergyPlus?
output: Using Beausoleil-Morrison's terminology regimes B1 and B2 are combined into just one B regime.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What is avoided by not distinguishing between surfaces directly blown on by fans and those away from fans?
output: To avoid requiring additional user input on the position of ZoneHVAC-type equipment within a zone there is no distinction between surfaces directly blown on by fans and those away from fans.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: Why is Fisher's correlation for horizontal free jets not used?
output: Fisher's correlation for horizontal free jets is not used to avoid requiring additional user input on the position and momentum of air terminal units and because the Coanda effect makes free horizontal jets difficult to maintain.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What models are used for all mechanical circulation from central air systems?
output: Ceiling diffuser models are used for all mechanical circulation from central air systems.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: Why does EnergyPlus support arbitrary geometry for surfaces?
output: EnergyPlus supports arbitrary geometry so surfaces can be tilted with respect to vertical or horizontal.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What equations are selected as defaults for tilted surfaces in EnergyPlus?
output: The h_c equations developed by Walton (1983) are selected as the defaults for tilted surfaces because they have a functional dependence on tilt angle.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What new equation did Fohanno and Polidari (2006) produce?
output: Fohanno and Polidari (2006) produced a new h_c equation for vertical walls inside buildings with a simple buoyancy flow regime.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What model is selected as the default for vertical walls in EnergyPlus?
output: In EnergyPlus the model by Fohanno and Polidari (2006) is selected as the default for vertical walls.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What new equation did Karadag (2009) produce?
output: Karadag (2009) produced a new h_c equation for ceiling surfaces that are actively chilled.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What model is selected as the default for actively chilled ceiling surfaces?
output: In EnergyPlus the model by Karadag (2009) is selected as the default for surfaces that have active in-ceiling cooling.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What standard does EnergyPlus strive to adhere to for inside face of windows?
output: EnergyPlus strives to adhere to International Standard Organization (ISO) Standard 15099-2003 which includes h_c equations for the inside face of windows.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What is the behavior of room airflows in relation to surfaces and ceiling diffusers?
output: Room airflows generally attach to surfaces and tend to match the flow regime of a ceiling diffuser much more often than a free jet.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What capability does EnergyPlus support regarding geometry?
output: EnergyPlus supports arbitrary geometry so surfaces can be tilted with respect to vertical or horizontal.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: How was Beausoleil-Morrison's adaptive convection algorithm originally structured?
output: Beausoleil-Morrison's adaptive convection algorithm was originally structured to use h_c equations that have no functional dependence on surface tilt angle.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: How do tilted surfaces perform compared to vertical or horizontal surfaces when buoyancy forces are significant?
output: Tilted surfaces perform differently than vertical or horizontal surfaces when buoyancy forces are significant.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: How does the EnergyPlus implementation expand the structure of the algorithm for tilted surfaces?
output: The EnergyPlus implementation expands the structure of the algorithm to include additional categories for tilted surfaces.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: Which equations are selected as the defaults for tilted surfaces in EnergyPlus and why?
output: The h_c equations developed by Walton (1983) are selected as the defaults for tilted surfaces because they have a functional dependence on tilt angle.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What did Fohanno and Polidari (2006) produce for vertical walls inside buildings?
output: Fohanno and Polidari (2006) produced a new h_c equation for vertical walls inside buildings with a simple buoyancy flow regime.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What theoretical approach did Fohanno and Polidari use for their h_c equation?
output: They used a theoretical approach based on integral formalism and uniform heat flux (rather than uniform temperature) that covers both laminar and turbulent flow situations.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: Which model is selected as the default for vertical walls in EnergyPlus?
output: In EnergyPlus the model by Fohanno and Polidari (2006) is selected as the default in place of the model by Alamdari and Hammond (1983) for vertical walls.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What new h_c equation did Karadag (2009) produce?
output: Karadag (2009) produced a new h_c equation for ceiling surfaces that are actively chilled.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What method did Karadag use to produce the new h_c equation?
output: He used computational fluid dynamics and various sized rooms and temperature conditions.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: Which model is selected as the default for actively chilled ceiling surfaces in EnergyPlus?
output: In EnergyPlus Karadag's model is selected as the default for surfaces that have active in-ceiling cooling (in place of the model by Alamdari and Hammond (1983) for unstable ceilings).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What standard did the International Standard Organization (ISO) complete and what does it include?
output: The International Standard Organization (ISO) completed Standard 15099-2003 which includes h_c equations for the inside face of windows.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: How does EnergyPlus strive to adhere to formal modeling standards?
output: EnergyPlus strives to adhere to formal modeling standards by including a larger structure for the adaptive algorithm that includes additional categories for windows in all flow regimes using ISO 15099-2003 models as the default for windows in natural convection flow regimes.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: To which tilt angles does the ISO 15099 model apply?
output: The ISO 15099 model applies to various tilt angles.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What new h_c equations did Goldstein and Novosalec (2010) produce?
output: Goldstein and Novosalec (2010) produced new h_c equations for forced air situations with ceiling slot diffusers along perimeters with significant glazing fractions.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What method did Goldstein and Novosalec use to produce their equations?
output: They used experiments with a full-sized test room.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: Which surfaces are the new equations by Goldstein and Novosalec selected as the default for?
output: These new equations are selected as the default for windows ceilings and floors when there is an active central air system.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What h_c equation is assigned to interior mass surfaces?
output: Interior mass surfaces are assigned the h_c equation that would apply (stable or unstable) to a horizontal upward-facing surface for each flow regime.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: How does the algorithm switch between forced mixed and natural flow regimes?
output: The algorithm switches between forced mixed and natural flow regimes by calculating the Richardson number Ri = Gr/Re^2 for the zone.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> equation
input: What is the formula for the Richardson number used in the algorithm?
output: Ri = Gr/Re^2

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What do large and small values of the Richardson number indicate?
output: Large values of Ri indicate buoyancy dominates while small values indicate forced flows dominate.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: How are opposing zone unit type equipment and central air type equipment assumed to affect air flow?
output: Opposing zone unit type equipment (with fans) are assumed to force air up walls and central air type equipment (with diffusers) are assumed to force air down walls.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: How many different categories for surfaces and options for h_c equation selections does the adaptive convection algorithm have?
output: The adaptive convection algorithm implemented in EnergyPlus for the inside face has a total of 45 different categories for surfaces and 29 different options for h_c equation selections.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What does 'unstable' refer to in the context of heat flow and buoyancy?
output: 'Unstable' refers to the direction of heat flow and the associated buoyancy relative to the surfaces where the natural tendency is to enhance flow in the sense that rising warmer air or falling cooler air is free to move away from the surface.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> equation

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What does 'stable' refer to in the context of heat flow and buoyancy?
output: 'Stable' refers to the direction of heat flow and the associated buoyancy relative to the surfaces where the natural tendency is to retard flow in the sense that rising warmer air or falling cooler air is driven against the surface.

output: h = \\left( \\left\\ \\left[1.5\\left(\\frac|ΔT|H\\right)^1/4\\right]^6 + \\left[1.23|ΔT|^2\\right]^1/6 \\right\\^1/2 + \\left\\ \\left[\\fracT_surf-T_SAT|ΔT|\\right] \\left[-0.199+0.190\\cdot ACH^0.8\\right] \\right\\^3 \\right)^1/3

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What does the text describe for heated zones?

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> equation
input: What is the equation for the heat transfer coefficient for heated zones?
output: The equation is \( h = 3.10\left| \Delta T \right|^0.17 \).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: Who conducted laboratory measurements for heated floor surfaces?
output: Awbi and Hatton (1999) conducted laboratory measurements for heated floor surfaces.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> equation
input: What is the correlation equation developed by Awbi and Hatton for heated floor surfaces?
output: The correlation equation is \( h = \frac2.175\left| \Delta T \right|^0.308D_h^0.076 \).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What does \( D_h \) represent in the equation for heated floor surfaces?
output: In the equation \( D_h = \frac4AP \) represents the hydraulic diameter of the horizontal surface where \( A \) is the area (m²) and \( P \) is the perimeter (m) of the entire zone.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What is the correlation developed by Awbi and Hatton for heated wall surfaces?

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> equation
input: What is the correlation equation developed by Awbi and Hatton for heated wall surfaces?
output: The correlation equation is \( h = \frac1.823\left| \Delta T \right|^0.293D_h^0.076 \).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What does \( D_h \) represent in the equation for heated wall surfaces?
output: In the equation \( D_h = \frac4AP \) represents the hydraulic diameter of the wall surface where \( A \) is the area (m²) and \( P \) is the perimeter (m) of the entire wall.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What technique did Beausoleil-Morrison use to develop correlations for mixed assisted walls?
output: Beausoleil-Morrison used blending techniques to combine correlations originally developed by Alamdari and Hammond (1983) and Fisher and Pedersen (1997).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> equation
input: What is the correlation equation for mixed assisted walls developed by Beausoleil-Morrison?
output: The correlation equation is \( h = \left( \left\ \left[1.5\left(\frac\left|\Delta T\right|H\right)^1/4\right]^6 + \left[1.23\left|\Delta T\right|^2\right]^1/6 \right\^1/2 + \left\ \left[\fracT_surf-T_SAT\left|\Delta T\right|\right] \left[-0.199+0.190\cdot ACH^0.8\right] \right\^3 \right)^1/3 \).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What is the reference temperature in the correlation for mixed assisted walls?
output: The reference temperature is the zone air temperature rather than the diffuser supply air temperature.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
input: What technique did Beausoleil-Morrison use to develop correlations for mixed opposing walls?

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> equation
input: What is the correlation equation for mixed opposing walls developed by Beausoleil-Morrison?
output: The correlation equation is \( h = \max \left\ \beginarrayl \left(\left\\left[1.5\left(\frac\left|\Delta T\right|H\right)^1/4\right]^6+\left[1.23\left|\Delta T\right|^2\right]^1/6\right\^1/2-\left\\left[\fracT_surf-T_SAT\left|\Delta T\right|\right]\cdot\left[-0.199+0.190\cdot ACH^0.8\right]\right\^3\right)^1/3 \\ 0.8\cdot \left\\left[1.5\left(\frac\left|\Delta T\right|H\right)^1/4\right]^6+\left[1.23\left|\Delta T\right|^2\right]\right\^1/6 \\ 0.8\cdot \left\\left[\fracT_surf-T_SAT\left|\Delta T\right|\right]\cdot\left[-0.199+0.190\cdot ACH^0.8\right]\right\ \endarray \right. \).

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text

output: The equation is: \n\\( h = \\left( \\left\\ \\left[ 1.4\\left( \\frac\\left| \\Delta T \\right|D_h \\right)^^\\raise0.7ex\\hbox1 \\!\\mathord\\left/ \\vphantom 1 4\\right.\\!\\lower0.7ex\\hbox4 \\right]^6 + \\left[ 1.63\\left| \\Delta T \\right|^\\raise0.7ex\\hbox1 \\!\\mathord\\left/ \\vphantom 1 3\\right.\\!\\lower0.7ex\\hbox3 \\right]^6 \\right\\^\\raise0.7ex\\hbox3 \\!\\mathord\\left/ \\vphantom 3 6\\right.\\!\\lower0.7ex\\hbox6 + \\left\\ \\left[ \\fracT_surf - T_SAT\\left| \\Delta T \\right| \\right]\\cdot\\left[ 0.159 + 0.116ACH^0.8 \\right] \\right\\^3 \\right)^\\raise0.7ex\\hbox1 \\!\\mathord\\left/ \\vphantom 1 3\\right.\\!\\lower0.7ex\\hbox3 \\)

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> equation

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> equation

output: Beausoleil-Morrison (2000) used blending techniques to combine correlations originally developed by Alamdari and Hammond (1983) and Fisher and Pedersen (1997) to create the following correlation is for ceilings where the flow driving forces include both mechanical forces and thermally Stable buoyancy.

instruction: Imagine you are a helpful assistant and building energy expert for the energyPlus Engineering Reference -> Chapter: Surface Heat Balance Manager / Processes -> Section: Inside Heat Balance -> text
